question.title: How do I call Scanner with Swing in Java?
question.body:
I am trying to start a console based Main.main() from a Swing GUI, but the Scanner doesn't accept any input, I think that scanner isnt running.

This is my code in the GUI:

bankBtn.addActionListener(e -> {
    dispose();
    // Start bank system in separate thread
    new Thread(() -> {
        Main.main(new String);
    }).start();
});

This is the beginning of Main:

public class Main {
    private static User user = null;

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);
        // ... rest

Problem: When I click the button, Main.main() starts and prints the console interface, but the Scanner doesn't respond to keyboard input. It seems like scanner.nextLine() is blocking but not receiving any input from the console.

Question: How can I properly start a console application with Scanner input from a Swing GUI? Is there a way to ensure the Scanner has access to System.in when started from a GUI thread?

I would be really grateful if somebody could help a young student.

V1:

bankBtn.addActionListener(e -> {
    dispose();
    Main.main(new String[0]);
});

V2:

bankBtn.addActionListener(e -> {
        dispose();
        SwingUtilities.invokeLater(() -> {
            new Thread(() -> {
                Main.main(new String[0]);
            }).start();
        });
    });

V3:

bankBtn.addActionListener(e -> {
        dispose();
        new Thread(() -> {
            Main.main(new String[0]);
        }).start();
    });

answers.body:
Let's start with a small example, where the use of the Scanner class works in a Swing application, and on the event thread.

public class ScannerInSwing extends JFrame {

   JButton button;
   JPanel panel;

   public ScannerInSwing() {
      panel = new JPanel( null );
      button = new JButton( "Start" );
      setBounds( 10, 10, 500, 500 );
      button.setBounds( 10, 10, 50, 50 ); 
      panel.add( button );
      add( panel );
      setDefaultCloseOperation( EXIT_ON_CLOSE );
      setVisible( true );
      button.addMouseListener( new MouseAdapter() {
         @Override
         public void mouseClicked( MouseEvent evt ) {            
            new Thread( () -> {
               Main.main( new String[]{} );
            }).start();
         }
      } );
   }

   public static void main( String[] args ) {
      EventQueue.invokeLater(() -> {
         new ScannerInSwing();
      });
   } 
}

public class User {
   String name;   
   public User( String n ) { name = n; }
   public String getName() { return name; }
}

public class Main {

   private static User user = null;

   public static void main( String[] args ) {
      Scanner scanner = new Scanner( System.in );
      System.out.println( "please, enter the name" );
      String userName = scanner.nextLine();
      user = new User( "John" );
      System.out.println( user.getName() );
   }
}

Now, it works, but is it a good implementation?, in my humble opinion, no, I don't know the context of your application, but invoking a class by means of its main method (obviating the class that starts the program), I don't think it's a good idea, I think it is better to create an object of the class (with the “extra” of being able to pass it any kind of parameters) and invoke their methods.

Let's make some changes:

  // in "ScannerInSwing" add the **main** atribute
Main main;

  // we modify the code executed by the listener, creating
  // a “Main” object and invoking its method “createUser”.
button.addMouseListener( new MouseAdapter() {
   @Override
   public void mouseClicked( MouseEvent evt ) {
      new Thread( () -> {
         main = new Main( panel );
         main.createUser();
      } ).start();
   }
} );

  // we remove the “main” method, and add ‘createUser’, and after 
  // instantiating the “User” object, we create a *JLabel*, and 
  // load it in the panel that we receive as a parameter.
public class Main {
   private User user = null;
   JPanel panel;
   
   public Main( JPanel pan ) {
      panel = pan;
   }
   
   public void createUser() {
      Scanner scanner = new Scanner( System.in );
      System.out.println( "please, enter the name" );
      String userName = scanner.nextLine();
      user = new User( userName );
      System.out.println( user.getName() );
      JLabel label = new JLabel( userName );
      label.setBounds( 100, 20, 80, 26 );
      panel.add( label );
      panel.repaint();
   }
}

As you can see, the possibilities are much greater and you remove the need to declare attributes and static methods (when they are not necessary).
